title: Nazi, 93, facing war crimes watched prisoners being led to death in gas chambers
text:

An SS guard who could be the last Nazi to stand trial for war crimes yesterday admitted seeing prisoners being led into gas chambers, never to return.

Bruno Dey told a court that he saw a group of 20 or 30 inmates being taken away. He said they were led into a gas chamber and the door was locked behind them. Then, he said he heard “screams and screams”.

Afterwards, it went quiet. But Dey insists that he did not know that the prisoners had been gassed.

Earlier in the trial in Hamburg, Dey had told the court that he was unaware that thousands of prisoners were murdered at Stutthof concentration camp, but nonetheless described the site as a “place of horror”.

The 93-year-old said that he did not voluntarily become an SS security guard, but was transferred from the army at age 17 due to a heart defect.

At Stutthof camp, in what is now Gdansk, Poland, Dey helped to oversee the killing of 5,230 people out of 66,000 who were murdered.

(Image: POOL/AFP via Getty Images)

He was just a small part of the Holocaust, which claimed six million lives. When the war ended he slipped away, like so many other fellow travellers, to build a new life in the new West Germany.

But justice has finally caught up with the father of two. He is now on trial in Hamburg for the part he played during the Second World War.

During interrogations he confessed to “hearing these screams from afar in the gas chamber, and before that they screamed for their lives and fought for their lives”.

Now, he is finally in the dock. He will likely enter the history books as the last person to answer for crimes of genocide committed during the Second World War.

(Image: Internet unknown)

Dey has previously admitted to seeing “hundreds” of bodies and said that he knew about the mass gassings. He said that he saw babies killed by being swung by the legs as their heads were smashed into concrete walls.

There are no living witnesses to verify his crimes, or to state exactly what he did or did not do within the perimeter of Stutthof.

He is being tried according to the principle of common purpose, on the grounds that he was working at the camp and therefore part of the Nazi conspiracy.

While denying any specific acts of cruelty or murder, he said in an interview with prosecutors on July 6, 2018: “I knew well that these murdered people were Jews who did not commit crimes. That they were only there because they were Jews.

“And they have as much a right to live and work freely as any other human being.”

SS records from Dey’s Death’s Head unit prove that he was on duty between August 9, 1944 and April 26, 1945, when the 5,230 prisoners were gassed, shot, hanged or otherwise killed.

He is being tried in the juvenile court in Hamburg because he was a teenager when he served in the camp. He faces up to 10 years in jail if found guilty.

His defence lawyer, Stefan Waterkamp, said: “He was not a supporter of the system.

“But because he lived near the concentration camp, he got his marching orders to Stutthof. My client now calls his whole life into question.

He feels sorry for what he did and said as much during his interrogation.“

According to the prosecutor’s office, one of the tasks of the “SS shooter” was to prevent the “escape, revolt and liberation of prisoners”.

(Image: PA)

The prosecution calls Dey, who lives in Hamburg with his wife “a coercer of the murder machine”.

Dey was born in 1926 in what is now Gdansk in Poland. He went on to join Hitler Youth, and spent six months in the army, but it is unknown if he saw action.

After the war, he was taken as a prisoner of war and released in December 1945. In 1955, he married and moved to Hamburg.

(Image: AFP/Getty Images)

There has been renewed interest in Germany in bringing concentration camp guards to justice since the 2012 prosecution of Ivan Demjanjuk, a former Ukrainian SS guard at Sobibor camp in Poland.

For the first time since the war ended, prosecutors said it was not necessary to have eyewitnesses, records of specific crimes or testimony of survivors.

Demjanjuk was tried simply because he was at the camp, and Dey faces the same rules.

In Germany, co-plaintiffs – relatives of the dead – can appear on the docket as accusers, and 12 will testify at Dey’s trial.

One is Judith Meisel, 94, from Minneapolis, US, who was in Stutthof at age 14 and lost her mother there.

(Image: Grab)

Her lawyer, Prof Dr Cornelius Nestler, 63, said: “Stutthof was organised mass murder and this mass murder was only possible with the help of the guards. The defendant helped to murder her mother”

Fania Brancovskaja, 97, from Lithuania, is another co-plaintiff. She lost all but one of her cousins in the Holocaust.

Her sister Riva was murdered in Stutthof. Her lawyer, Onur Ozata, said: “The trial is very important for my client.

She hopes that this will not let her family murdered by the Nazis, and all the victims of the [Holocaust], be forgotten.

“She also hopes [it] can send a signal against rising anti-Semitism in Europe.”

Chief Prosecutor Lars Mahnke called Dey “a small cog in the killing machine. But it is right that the word knows what he did and what went on at Stutthof”.
description: SS guard Bruno Dey, now 93, is standing trial in Hamburg after justice finally caught up with him
